title: Electronic cigarettes for smoking cessation and reduction. Summary of the evidence and implications for public health programmes
display_name: Electronic cigarettes for smoking cessation and reduction. Summary of the evidence and implications for public health programmes

author.au_affiliation_raw: Professor of Medicine, Head, Medicine Unit 2 and Clinical Epidemiology Unit, Christian Medical College, Vellore 632004, India
Professor of Psychiatry, Director, Cochrane South Asia, Christian Medical College Vellore 632004, India

ab: A Cochrane systematic review identified eleven studies (2 RCTs involving 957 participants and nine Cohort studies involving 1993 participants) that gave electronic cigarettes (EC) to subjects, who were current smokers to help them stop smoking. The study settings were varied from the USA, Europe, and South Africa and some were online surveys (from Europe). The RCTs found study found some evidence that participants using an EC were more likely to have abstained from smoking for at least six months compared with participants using placebo EC. However the GRADE of evidence was low. The one study that compared EC to nicotine patch found no significant difference in six-month abstinence rates, again with very low GRADE evidence. A higher number of people were able to reduce cigarette consumption by at least half with ECs compared with placebo ECs and nicotine patch, again with low and very low GRADE of evidence. The Cohort studies showed that ECs did reduce abstinence at 6, 12, 18 and 24 months as well as a ≥50% reduction of baseline cigarette consumption at the same time periods. The review did not find any increase in serious adverse events comparing ECs with placebo or nicotine patch. The review concluded that ECs help smokers to stop smoking long-term compared with placebo ECs. It did not find difference between EC and patch in this regard. It suggested that ECs appear to help smokers unable to stop smoking altogether to reduce their cigarette consumption, when compared with placebo ECs and nicotine patches. They found no evidence of harm with short term EC use. They, however, caution that the grade of evidence overall was low. Review on which this evidence summary is based: McRobbie H, Bullen C, Hartmann-Boyce J, Hajek P. Electronic cigarettes for smoking cessation and reduction. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2014, Issue 12. Art. No.: CD010216. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD010216.pub2.This evidence summary presents an overview of the findings and the implications for developed and developing countries. For further details, please read the full review that can be downloaded, free of charge (through various funded provisions) in most parts of the world, from The Cochrane Library (www.thecochranelibrary.com). This evidence summary presents an overview of the findings and the implications for developed and developing countries. For further details, please read the full review that can be downloaded, free of charge (through various funded provisions) in most parts of the world, from The Cochrane Library (www.thecochranelibrary.com). The use of tobacco including smoking cigarettes is among the major risk factors for noncommunicable diseases including cardiovascular, respiratory and cancers. Smoking cessation rates by voluntary efforts are very poor.1Hughes J.R. Keely J. Naud S. Shape of the relapse curve and long-term abstinence among untreated smokers.Addiction. 2004; 99: 29-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (957) Google Scholar Assisted methods such as behavioral interventions and nicotine patches and gums have poor long-term abstinence rates probably because of a lack of sensory and behavioral aspects associated with them. In order to overcome this, EC, which are electronic vaporizing devices broadly similar in appearance to cigarettes and contain propylene glycol and glycerol, with or without nicotine and flavors have been tried. They provide sensations and experience similar to cigarettes.2Barbeau A.M. Burda J. Siegel M. Perceived efficacy of e-cigarettes versus nicotine replacement therapy among successful e-cigarette users: a qualitative approach.Addict Sci Clin Pract. 2013; 8: 5Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar Those that contain nicotine are called ‘nicotine EC’ and nicotine-free EC as ‘placebo EC’ in the review. The EC are used for two reasons smoking cessation or reduction in smoking. The harmful effects of long-term use of ECs are also an issue to patients and health care providers. Review objectives. The objective is to evaluate the efficacy of EC for helping people, who smoke to achieve long-term abstinence (Table 1).Table 1Summary and critical appraisal of the systematic review.What did the review authors search for?What did the review find?Types of studies1. Randomized controlled trials, in which smokers are randomized to ECs or to a control condition, which measure abstinence rates or changes in cigarette consumption at six months or longer.2. Randomized cross-over trials and cohort follow-up studies with follow-up of greater than a week, for assessment of adverse events.Two RCTs (662 participants) met the inclusion criteria for the primary outcome.Two RCTs and 11 cohort studies (1090 patients) met the inclusion criteria for adverse events.SettingThe authors looked for interventions from countries irrespective of economic strata and irrespective of the patients clinical setting.The two RCTs were from community setting in Italy and New Zealand.The cohort studies were mostly from Europe.ParticipantsPeople defined as current smokers at enrolment into the trial.Participants can be motivated or unmotivated to quit.One RCT from New Zealand were motivated to quit. The second RCT from Italy were those not motivated to quit.Some cohort studies had participants, who wanted to quit while others, who were not motivated or, who had tried to quit and failed.InterventionsThey compared ECs with placebo ECs, ECs versus alternative smoking cessation aids, including NRT or no intervention, and ECs added to standard smoking cessation treatment (behavioral or pharmacological or both) with standard treatment alone.One RCT compared Elusion brand EC (first generation technology) with cartridges containing 16 mg nicotine, or 21 mg/24-h nicotine patches, or an EC with cartridges without nicotine (placebo EC), for 12 weeks following a target quit date (TQD). The ECs were couriered to participants, and those allocated to the patch arm were mailed a voucher to exchange for NRT at a pharmacy. All participants received an invitation to access phone- or text-based support, although this was accessed by fewer than 10%. The EC used in this study delivered only low levels of nicotine.The second RCT had three arms with Categoria brand EC with disposable cartridges containing 7.2 mg nicotine or 0 mg nicotine (placebo EC) for 12 weeks. The third arm used cartridges containing 7.2 mg nicotine for six weeks followed by 5.2 mg nicotine for another six weeks.The prospective cohort studies had different brands of EC with different concentrations of nicotine. The other observational studies were surveys, which did not mention the type of EC.OutcomesPrimary outcomesCessation at the longest follow-up point, which was at least six months from the start of the intervention, measured on an intention-to-treat basis using the strictest definition of abstinence, preferring biochemically validated results were reported.Secondary outcomesReduction in cigarette use at the longest follow-up point, which was at least six months from the start of the intervention, measured on an intention-to-treat basis confirmed by a reduction in biomarkers of exposure (e.g., carbon monoxide, thiocyanate, and other markers of tobacco use), if reported.Adverse eventsData were collected from both RCT as well as the observational studies on any adverse events at one week or longer, serious and non-serious, from the included studies.Both the RCTS as well as the observational studies presented data on abstinence rates as well as reduction in use.Adverse events were mentioned in the results of the RCTs as well as observational studies.Date of the last search: 25 September 2014Funding sources: Queen Mary University of London, UK and the University of Auckland, New Zealand provided salary, office space and library resources for the authors. Some authors had received funding from EC manufacturers, which they declared.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on smoking cessation versus placebo from the RCTsIn the two studies (662 patients) there was a significant reduction in smoking RR 2.29, 95%CI (1.05–4.96). However the GRADE quality of evidence was low, due to indirectness of evidence as in one trial the EC had very low dose nicotine and imprecision as the number of events were low overall. There was no heterogeneity in the results.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on smoking cessation versus nicotine replacement therapy from the RCTsOne study (584 patients) showed no significant difference RR1.26 95%CI (0.68–2.34) with very low quality evidence by GRADE.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on smoking reduction (50% reduction from baseline) versus placebo from the RCTsIn the two studies (662 patients), there was a significant reduction in smoking RR 1.31, 95%CI (1.02–1.68). However the GRADE quality of evidence was low, due to indirectness of evidence as in one trial the EC had very low dose nicotine and imprecision as the number of events were low overall.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on smoking reduction (50% reduction from baseline) versus nicotine replacement therapy from the RCTsOne study (546 patients) showed significant difference RR1.41 95%CI (1.20–1.67) with very low quality evidence by GRADE. It was downgraded one level due to indirectness. The electronic cigarette used in the study was not very effective at delivering nicotine. It was also downgraded two levels due to imprecision. Only one included study, with small number of events in each arm.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on smoking cessation among observational studiesOne prospective Cohort with patients motivated to quit smoking found 44% (21/48) abstinent at 6 months among the EC users. In two prospective cohorts of unmotivated subjects the abstinence rate was 23% (9/40) at 6 months and 15% (6/40) and 13% (5/40) respectively at 18 and 24 months.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on smoking reduction (50% reduction from baseline) among observational studiesOne prospective Cohort with patients motivated to quit smoking found 27% (13/48) reduced by 50% at 6 months among the EC users. In two prospective cohorts of unmotivated subjects the rate was 33% (13/40) at 6 months and 28% (11/40) at 18 and 24 months.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on harmful side effectsNone of the RCTs or cohort studies reported any serious adverse events (SAEs) that were considered to be plausibly related to EC use. Mouth and throat irritation being the most frequently reported AEs in EC users.What were the effects Electronic cigarettes on smoking cessation among RCT and observational studiesAmong 1090 (8 studies: 2 RCTs, 6 cohort) none reported any serious AEs that were related to EC use. Neither RCT detected a significant difference in AEs between intervention and control groups. Cohort studies found mouth and throat irritation, dissipating over time, to be the most frequently reported AEs in EC users. The quality of the evidence was rated as low due to risk of bias as 6 of 8 were cohort studies and imprecision as only one trial compared EC with nicotine replacement therapy.What were the conclusions of the review?The review concluded that “There is evidence from two trials that ECs help smokers to stop smoking long-term compared with placebo ECs. The lack of difference between the effects of ECs compared with nicotine patches found in one trial is uncertain. ECs appear to help smokers unable to stop smoking altogether to reduce their cigarette consumption, when compared with placebo ECs and nicotine patches. No evidence emerged that short-term EC use is associated with health risk.” “However, the small number of trials, low event rates and wide confidence intervals around the estimates mean that our confidence in the result is rated ‘low’ by GRADE standards.”What were the assessments of the overall quality of the evidence?The study quality was assessed using the Cochrane risk of bias tool, which looks at the randomization process, allocation concealment, blinding, completeness of outcome data and possible selective reporting. Both RCTs were evaluated to have low overall risk of bias. One RCT had 22% lost to follow-up rate.Non-RCTsThe observational studies by nature of design were categorized as being at high risk of selection bias. The three surveys did not validate self-reported abstinence, excluded EC users, who stopped smoking, and two do not provide a clear definition of abstinence. The lack of intervention or contact with researchers means that there is unlikely to be a significant performance or detection bias.The Five cohort studies included biochemical validation of participants and so were graded as being at low risk of detection bias. Rates of follow-up were mixed-one followed up all participants, while another had one-year data from only 367 (28%) of the 1329 people that completed the baseline survey. For many of the cohort studies the authors were unable to determine prespecified outcomes and hence rated these as being at unclear risk of reporting bias. One did not provide a definition of abstinence and it was unclear if the completion of the programme was at six months after enrolment, or at an earlier time point.Strengths and limitationsThe strengths of the review include following the Cochrane methods rigorously and including both RCT as well as observational studies. Overall the quality of the evidence appeared to be low. The studies were from developed countries only. The limitations include the small number of studies and study participants in the RCT and inadequate data from both RCT and observational studies to assess all outcomes that were planned.Did the results and conclusions of the review differ from other reviews on this topic?The results of this systematic review are similar to another comprehensive review that suggested benefit.3Hajek P. Etter J.-F. Benowitz N. Eissenberg T. McRobbie H. Electronic cigarettes: review of use, content, safety, effects on smokers, and potential for harm and benefit.Addiction. 2014; 109: 1801-1810Crossref PubMed Scopus (375) Google Scholar A large population survey4Brown J. Beard E. Kotz D. Michie S. West R. Real-world effectiveness of e-cigarettes when used to aid smoking cessation: a cross-sectional population study.Addiction. 2014; 109: 1531-1540Crossref PubMed Scopus (343) Google Scholar of that had smoked within the previous 12 months and made at least one quit attempt during that period found that attempting to stop smoking with the help of ECs were more likely to succeed than those using NRT or trying to quit unaided. This benefit remained after adjusting for confounders, including nicotine dependence.A World Health Organization review5Grana R. Benowitz N. Glantz S.A. E-cigarettes: a scientific review.Circulation. 2014; 129: 1972-1986Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar which pooled data from five population-based studies (four longitudinal and one cross-sectional) found EC use associated with a significantly lower chance of quitting smoking (OR 0.61, 95% CI 0.50–0.75). Three studies included in this review were not included in the present systematic review. One was6Popova L. Ling P.M. Alternative tobacco product use and smoking cessation: a national study.Am J Public Health. 2013; 103: 923-930Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar was cross-sectional, one7Adkison S.E. O’Connor R.J. Bansal-Travers M. et al.Electronic nicotine delivery systems: international tobacco control four-country survey.Am J Prev Med. 2013; 44: 207-215Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (479) Google Scholar used a longitudinal design, participants were only asked about EC use at follow-up, and one8Vickerman K.A. Carpenter K.M. Altman T. Nash C.M. Zbikowski S.M. Use of electronic cigarettes among state tobacco cessation quitline callers.Nicotine Tob Res Off J Soc Res Nicotine Tob. 2013; 15: 1787-1791Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar surveyed people at seven months after enrolment into a Quitline service and asked them about EC use retrospectively. The authors were unable to determine how much EC use occurred at baseline or how many clients used ECs as part of their quit attempt. Also, smokers calling the Quitline were those, who did not benefit from EC use and so this only included ‘treatment failures’ and cannot determine the effects of EC use overall.What further research is required?Placebos EC provide a sensory-neural input along with being placebos. This may or may not reduce the impact of the EC with nicotine. Future studies should focus on comparing ECs with ‘usual care’ or minimal treatment, and with alternative pharmacological and behavioral treatments.Data are also needed on the proportions of smokers, who successfully quit smoking with the help of ECs and, who continue to use ECs long-term and the proportion, who eventually become nicotine-free.The ECs studied should have good nicotine delivery and be current with respect to reliability and user satisfaction. The trials should preferably be pragmatic trials and of adequate sample size to detect meaningful differences.What are the implications of the review for public health?This systematic review suggests that ECs may have a role in helping chronic smokers quit smoking or reduce the usage by at least 50%. However, adequately powered, pragmatic trials including developing countries are required before ECs are suggested as a standard of care. We suggest they be advocated by physicians as part of research studies till more evidence is available. Open table in a new tab The authors have none to declare. title: Significant effect of education & income on cancer control: Policy consideration for third world
display_name: Significant effect of education & income on cancer control: Policy consideration for third world

author.au_affiliation_raw: Professor, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, King George Medical University, Lucknow, UP, India
Resident, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, King George Medical University, Lucknow, UP, India
Resident, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, King George Medical University, Lucknow, UP, India
Resident, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, King George Medical University, Lucknow, UP, India
Resident, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, King George Medical University, Lucknow, UP, India

ab: BackgroundHead and neck squamous cell cancer (HNSCC) is maximally encountered in India across the globe, and the environmental influences/interactions leading to cancer particularly education and income are very different in the developed countries than the third world.Material and methodsA prospective assessment of 707 histologically proven HNSCC patients was undertaken regarding the possible role of 2 determinants viz. education and income on cancer prevalence. Standard questionnaires were filled up for the outpatients in the department of otolaryngology and variables such as demographics, site of involvement, the education and family income were analyzed accordingly.ObservationsThe cancer was seen more among those with the education status of less than grade V (58%), than between VI and VIII grade (21%) or between IX and XII grade (8.5%) and higher. Of those with the education category of less that grade V, oral cavity was the most common site involved (29%). The cancer rates among income category of less than Rs. 1000/- (46%) was significantly more than those of Rs. 1001–2000 (29%) and Rs. 2001–4000 (10%). Thereafter there was a drastic fall in the cancer rates among the further higher income categories.ConclusionsTwo points have emerged from this study; that is likely to have the highest impact on cancer control: (1) implementing compulsory education till class VI and (2) Enhancing family income to Rs. 4000/INR per month. These are likely to have a complicated interaction with various procarcinogenic practices and environment and their correction is very likely to reduce the cancer occurrence through prevention.

ab: Breast implant-related infections are uncommon and are usually caused by skin commensals. However, with the routine use of perioperative broad-spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis, infections caused by rare organisms are being increasingly reported. This report summarises a rare infection of breast prosthesis in a young female who underwent augmentation mammoplasty using silicone prosthesis. Prosthesis removal and a prolonged course of anti-microbial therapy were required for eradication of the infection.

title: Epidemiology of childhood diseases in an urban resettlement colony in Delhi
display_name: Epidemiology of childhood diseases in an urban resettlement colony in Delhi

author.au_affiliation_raw: Resident, Department of Community Medicine, Maulana Azad Medical College, New Delhi, India
Director Professor, Department of Community Medicine, Maulana Azad Medical College, New Delhi, India
Resident, Department of Community Medicine, Maulana Azad Medical College, New Delhi, India
Resident, Department of Community Medicine, Maulana Azad Medical College, New Delhi, India

ab: ObjectiveTo assess the prevalence and determinants of childhood diseases which are covered under IMNCI in an urban resettlement colony in Delhi.Materials and methodsA community-based cross-sectional study was carried out in Gokulpuri area in Delhi from January to December 2014 among 550 mothers/caretakers who were residing in the study area and selected by stratified random sampling. Data were collected using a pre-tested semi-structured questionnaire consisting of items on socio-demographic details and history of acute respiratory infections (ARI), diarrhoea, measles and malaria in the past 15 days. Data were analyzed by using SPSS 17. Chi-square test/Fisher's exact test was used for testing any significance of association and “p” value <0.05 was considered statistically significant.ResultsThe study showed that 282 (51.2%) children were 1–5 years old and 290 (52.7%) were male. Prevalence of ARI was found to be 16% followed by diarrhoea to be 4.2% in the last 15 days. There was no case of measles in the area. 123 (22.3%) were found to be moderately malnourished. Prevalence of ARI was significantly less in exclusively breastfed children compared to not exclusively breastfed children (p = 0.002). For other childhood diseases, the difference was not statistically significant.ConclusionThe childhood diseases had a considerable burden in the area. Protective factors like colostrum and exclusive breastfeeding should be promoted by raising awareness among caregivers. Intensive health education campaigns should be carried out in the area to prevent childhood diseases.

ab: Objectives and background dataUrban India has seen dramatic improvements in per capita income, life expectancy and educational level in the past century. This should translate to better awareness and utilization of prosthodontic treatment options. The aim of this study was to gauge the veracity of the above hypothesis.Materials and methodsA total of 1200 partially dentate and edentate patients visiting 2 dental hospitals for prosthodontic rehabilitation were randomly selected and administered a questionnaire and clinical examination. Data including distance of patient residence from hospital facility, patient desired prosthodontic treatment, prosthodontist's assessment of required treatment and disparity between demand and assessed treatment need were collected, evaluated, and statistically analyzed utilizing Graph Pad Prism Software with α = 2 and p < 0.05.ResultsForty-nine percent of the patients visiting the hospitals disagreed with professional advice. The reasons recorded for this included lack of awareness (39%), financial constraints (20%) and clinical limitations (32%) (p < 0.01).ConclusionA significant disparity was found between professional prosthodontic advice and patient desired management, possibly due to lack of understanding or communication between the prosthodontist and patient. This may be overcome by increasing awareness aids and programs in the hospital set up, and more time given to communication.

title: Clinical epidemiology in developing countries: Current situation and suggestions for the Indian context
display_name: Clinical epidemiology in developing countries: Current situation and suggestions for the Indian context

author.au_affiliation_raw: Professor & HOD Paediatrics, Dr. S.M. C.S.I. Medical College, Karakonam, Kerala, India
author.institution_display_name: Dr. Somervell Memorial CSI Medical College and Hospital

ab: BackgroundIn India, epidemiological services are well developed and epidemiology teaching is very much part of curriculum from undergraduate to doctorate level of studies. In spite of all the initiatives to sensitize physicians towards clinical epidemiology (CE), this academic discipline is still not popular as it should be. The development of CE teaching and the present situation along with way forward are discussed in this article.ObjectivesThis review article is aimed to describe the evolution of CE in India and critically look into the concept and scope of CE and evidence-based medicine (EBM) in the Indian setting.MethodsThis paper is a review of the status of 'clinical epidemiology – popularization' in India and the scope for further progress towards this direction.ResultsThe development of CE has taken a new pace after the introduction of EBM. Both CE and EBM are propagated by INCLEN-trained faculty mostly among medical students and teachers. The paper also looks into the linkages between public health epidemiology and CE in the context of involvement of clinical epidemiologists in public health programs.ConclusionsAfter discussing the directions for future, the paper proposes the inception of CE unit at each medical college and also the objectives and structure of such a unit. The article concludes emphasizing the need of public health orientation of CE, the importance of promotion of epidemiology in developing countries through capacity building, and allocation of dedicated funds towards popularization of CE. There is also an urgent need for replication and scale-up of clinical epidemiology unit (CEU) model to other medical colleges.
